name: Language
overview:
This class allows you interact with Google Cloud Natural Language.

First, install google-cloud with npm:

$ npm install --save google-cloud

If you are running your app on Google Compute Engine, you won't need to worry about supplying connection configuration options to google-cloudâ€” we figure that out for you.

However, if you're running your app elsewhere, you will need to provide project details to authenticate API requests.

Compute Engine

var gcloud = require('google-cloud'); var language = gcloud.language();

Elsewhere

var gcloud = require('google-cloud'); var language = gcloud.language({ projectId: 'grape-spaceship-123', keyFilename: '/path/to/keyfile.json' });

The full set of options which can be passed to google-cloud are outlined in our Authentication guide.
description:
The object returned from gcloud.language gives you access to the methods that will run detections and annotations from your text.

To learn more about Google Cloud Natural Language, see the official Google Cloud Natural Language API Documentation.

methods.name: Language
methods.description:
The Google Cloud Natural Language API provides natural language understanding technologies to developers, including sentiment analysis, entity recognition, and syntax analysis. This API is part of the larger Cloud Machine Learning API.

The Cloud Natural Language API currently supports English for sentiment analysis and English, Spanish, and Japanese for entity analysis and syntax analysis.

methods.name: annotate
methods.description:
Run an annotation of a block of text.

NOTE: This is a convenience method which doesn't require creating a language/document object. If you are only running a single detection, this may be more convenient. However, if you plan to run multiple detections, it's easier to create a language/document object.

examples.caption: See language/document#annotate for a detailed breakdown of the arguments your callback will be executed with.
examples.code:
function callback(err, entities, apiResponse) {}

language.annotate('Hello!', callback);

examples.caption: Or, provide a reference to a file hosted on Google Cloud Storage.
Specify HTML content.
Verbose mode may also be enabled for more detailed results.

params.name: content
params.description: • Inline content or a Storage File object.

params.name: options.verbose
params.description: • Enable verbose mode for more detailed results. Default: false

methods.name: document
methods.description:
Create a Document object for an unknown type. If you know the type, use the appropriate method below:

  • language#html - For HTML documents.
  • language#text - For text documents.

examples.code: var document = language.document('Inline content of an unknown type.');

examples.caption: Or, provide a reference to a file hosted on Google Cloud Storage.
You can now run detections on the document. See language/document for a complete list of methods available.
examples.code: document.detectEntities(function(err, entities) {});

params.name: config
params.description: • Configuration object, the inline content of the document, or a Storage File object.

params.name: options.content
params.description: • If using config as an object to specify the encoding and/or language of the document, use this property to pass the inline content of the document or a Storage File object.

methods.name: html
methods.description: Create a Document object from an HTML document. You may provide either inline HTML content or a Storage File object (see storage/file).

examples.code: var document = language.html('<h1>Document Title</h1>');

examples.caption: Or, provide a reference to a file hosted on Google Cloud Storage.
You can now run detections on the document. See language/document for a complete list of methods available.
examples.code: document.detectEntities(function(err, entities) {});

params.name: content
params.description: • Inline HTML content or a Storage File object.

methods.name: text
methods.description: Create a Document object from a text-based document. You may provide either inline text content or a Storage File object (see storage/file).

examples.code: var document = language.text('This is using inline text content.');

examples.caption: Or, provide a reference to a file hosted on Google Cloud Storage.
You can now run detections on the document. See language/document for a complete list of methods available.
examples.code: document.detectEntities(function(err, entities) {});
